There will be traffic from tourists visiting the National Library, the new science centre, the High Court and the National Gallery. I hope that before too long the archives building will also be in the area. Just this week we saw the sort of splendid exhibitions that the Australian Archives can put on in relation to matters that are relevant to the growth of this country with the exhibition on the 60 years of this building, which is definitely worth seeing. This set of traffic lights needs to be put in for the greater safety of those who use the area travelling to and from work and of other Australians who come here as tourists and who want to be able to move freely and safely around the area. I trust that the Senate will approve the installation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 March, on motion by Senator Vigor:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite a lot of private member's Bills come before this place these days. They are something of a hobby of the Australian Democrats, as honourable senators will know. They all deal with matters of considerable importance. I cannot think of any which has more implications, and more gathering implications as time passes, for the Australian community-indeed, for everybody who flies in an aircraft who does not smoke-than the Air Navigation (Smoking) Amendment Bill. The non-smoking zones in aircraft are a farce. They are a joke, and not a very good joke either. I think it is very plain to everybody that there is no proper separation between the non-smoking and the smoking areas of aircraft. There is absolutely no protection to enable people in the non-smoking zones to get away from smoke. That is really the point that we have to look at.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a farcical situation. Travellers who elect to go into a non-smoking zone-it is called that-are not being put in a non-smoke zone, a zone which is not contaminated by smoke. Evidence is gathering that one does not die just by being the person who smokes the cigarette, the pipe or whatever. The issue being debated in this Bill is, in fact, whether each of us has the basic human right not to be harmed, not to be disabled and not to be killed by another person. Smoking does those things. I do not in any sense try to prevent anybody-it could be Senator Button-from smoking. If people want to kill themselves in such a silly way that is their business. All I say is that they ought not to have the right to contribute to the lack of welfare of other people by indulging in that rather strange and curious habit. I often wonder what people who came from outer space to this planet and who saw some of its inhabitants with these little sticks in their mouths from which smoke emerged with a little piece of fire on the end would think. It would seem to them to be one of the more curious perversions and aberrations of this new and strange species that they had found. I say this with all the zeal of the convert as an ex-smoker-fortunately one of long standing. I have, analogously, the right to take my car on to a public road and to drive it just as Senator Button has the right to take out a cigarette and smoke it. But I also have the responsibility to ensure that in driving my car I do not endanger anybody else's life or well-being. I think that is a well established principle of law. Indeed, a great deal of our body of law is based on that very simple principle.

The next stage we have to consider is whether smoking is a hazardous activity. Chemical examination of the smoke from the lit end of a cigarette shows that it contains at least 18 known animal carcinogens. Interestingly enough, some of them are in greater concentration in the smoke that enters the air than in the smoke directly inhaled by the smoker. This is a little known fact but it is so. It has been estimated reliably that seven hours in a smoke filled room or cabin will produce toxin levels in a non-smoker equivalent to those caused by that person smoking three cigarettes. In a report published in this month's issue of Community Health Studies, the journal of the Public Health Association of Australia and New Zealand, Professor Bruce Armstrong is reported as estimating that 136 Australians die each year as a direct result of inhaling the products of other people's smoking. That figure plainly is a statistical one and not one which is taken completely out of the air. It is probably somewhere near the truth. It may be considerably less than the true figure.

In February of this year Oxford University Emeritus Professor of Medicine, Sir Richard Doll, who has done some excellent work in this area and who is a very much respected authority, said that 25 per cent of all lung cancer cases were due to the inhalation of other people's tobacco smoke. He said that in his opinion, cigarette smoking was one of the world's most harmful atmospheric pollutants and that passive smoking posed a danger 50 times greater than asbestos poisoning.

When we consider those facts and the amount of time, effort and thought that we give to other contaminants in the atmosphere, especially asbestos, it should be some indication that this is a Bill of more than ordinary importance. Indeed, I note that there are 11 honourable senators on the speakers list. I hope that the Government will allow the Bill sufficient time, even if it is Government time, to go through its second reading and other stages. If it does, I am sure that Parliament will have done something of great importance and will be creating a milestone piece of legislation. As the facts emerge in the debate, such as those from such an important authority to which I referred, I cannot believe that any honourable senator would have it on his conscience not to pass the Bill. If the Government does not allow the Bill to pass so that we can tidy up a matter of so much importance to the community, it will be reprehensible.

Sir Richard Doll said that 13 studies of the relationship between lung cancer and passive smoking had all shown a link, and that cancer from passive smoking could also be caused in the mouth, larynx, oesophagus, bladder, pancreas and kidneys. That is a pretty good cocktail of cancers that a smoker in an aircraft can inflict on his or her fellow passengers.
The United States Surgeon-General last year issued a report stating:
. . . involuntary smoking is a cause of disease, including lung cancer, in healthy non smokers.

That is the United States Surgeon-General, not some wild-eyed anti-tobacco lobby. Actually, I do not blame tobacco lobbies for being wild-eyed when they obtain such little recognition from the Government, even though the facts are so appalling. The report continued:

. . . the children of parents who smoke compared with the children of non-smoking parents have an increased frequency of respiratory infections, increased respiratory symptoms and smaller rates of increase in lung function as the lung matures.
In relation to smoking in enclosed spaces such as aeroplanes, the report said:
The simple separation of smokers and non-smokers within the same air space may reduce but does not eliminate the exposure of non-smokers to environmental tobacco smoke.
That confirms the point I made when I commenced my speech. That report from the United States was based on the findings of more than 60 studies into the effects of smoking on non-smokers.

A recent report by the United States Worldwatch Institute said that nearly 20 per cent of deaths in the United States and Europe were linked to cigarette smoking, and that passive smoking by non-smokers inhaling ambient smoke causes as many as 5,000 deaths a year in the United States. Leading United States companies are now moving towards restricting smoking after realising that each smoker costs them an average of $940 per year through sick leave and the decreased productivity of the smoker and the smokers' non-smoking associates. That, of course, is another aspect of the smoking problem that is of enormous importance.

At this stage in my speech, it is important to examine the reasons why nothing is done about smoking. It is a pretty sorry commentary. Some very dedicated people in the community are extremely concerned about the effects of smoking. They are especially concerned about tobacco advertising, which encourages children to smoke. That happens; there is no doubt about that. On the face of it, it would appear that the Government's lack of desire to do anything about the problem is based on the pressure on two groups. The first is the pressure of the tobacco lobby on members of parliament; the other is the pressure of the tobacco lobby on the media, which carries a very heavy responsibility. It is well known that newspapers, television and radio stations take advertising to make money, and one of the better sources of revenue is tobacco advertising. That is not a good reason for smoking to continue. If there is any sense of responsibility in the Australian media, and I believe that there is, it must bite the bullet, and the sooner the better.

We have in the community an extremely dangerous activity, and one that is demonstrated throughout the world, by the most eminent of authorities, to injure and kill people on a scale that is not matched by any other drug. Members of the community and the media howl and scream about marihuana, heroin and other illegal drugs, yet the statistics prove that the enormous preponderance of hospitalisation and death in this community as a result of drug abuse comes from the use of one legalised drug-tobacco. By far and away, the next largest group of deaths, although, surprisingly, it is much smaller, is caused by another legal drug-alcohol. The so-called illegal drugs, those that we complain about young people using, represent only a tiny proportion, just a few per cent, of the deaths caused in this and every other community through the use of drugs.

I implore members of this Parliament and the media to exercise a proper sense of responsibility and to understand that the evidence shows that it is not simply a matter of whether people smoke. If people smoke and kill themselves, that is their business, but it is the business of the community and this Parliament if, as the figures so strikingly demonstrate, every day people die from inhaling smoke from other people's cigarettes. I would have thought that any smoker with a conscience would want to consider that matter sufficiently to agree with the aims of the Bill-that a smoker should be able to get on an aircraft for a relatively short journey and refrain from smoking. There is no way that people also on the flight can get away from a smoker, even though there is supposed to be a non-smokers' zone.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot step outside for a fag.
—Certainly not. One cannot step outside for a fag and one cannot step outside if a cigarette is smoked in front of one. Non-smoker areas are not non-smoker areas. That is an important distinction.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill becomes all the more important because, unfortunately, the use of tobacco world wide has grown by nearly 75 per cent over the past two decades. That is an absolute indictment of our society. It is also an indication of the tremendous strength and power of the tobacco lobby. Somehow, it has been able to persuade the Government, young people and people everywhere that there is nothing wrong with smoking, that it is not dangerous, and that not only should it continue but also it should be at an increased rate. Direct health costs, health risks to passive smokers and the economic costs grow proportionately with the increase in the number of smokers. Smoking is now increasing by 2.1 per cent a year-faster than the world's population is increasing. The world-wide cost to lives from smoking now approaches-it is a figure well worth noting-2 1/2 million deaths a year. That is almost 5 per cent of all deaths in the international community. If there were any other epidemic of that size, we would be scandalised by it.

We rightly talk about the acquired immune deficiency syndrome, the problem that it represents and the deaths that it causes. AIDS is disgraceful, shameful and bad-but smoking is okay! I cannot understand that curious ambivalence in society. The dear old guy who smokes on an aeroplane is perfectly respectable. He is not, he is a killer--

TALK.START.PARA: —Now, Senator Mason, do not go overboard.
—I apologise to Senator Button. In my enthusiasm I was carried away. I have a great respect for Senator Button's humanity and sense of responsibility. Maybe I am getting through to him.
—Nothing ruins a good cause like some people who embrace it-like you, for example.

—I have confessed to Senator Button that I have the zeal of a convert. He can also be a convert and be as zealous as I am. To go back to this rather dismal catalogue of the consequences of smoking, in the United States of America tobacco kills 13 times as many people as do hard drugs-that is a very interesting point when we consider the time and attention that people give to wringing their hands over hard drugs-and eight times as many as are killed in road accidents. Passive smokers are three times more likely to die of lung cancer than they would be if they were not forced to inhale the products of someone else's addiction. When speaking of passive smokers, I imagine these are people who are regularly exposed to this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Passive smoking is also very harmful to the next generation, to unborn children. Nicotine, numerous toxic chemicals and radioactive plutonium may all interfere with foetal development, which is very sensitive. The effects of such contaminants at the very beginning of life can be greatly multiplied. The effects of passive smoking in children can last a lifetime because they delay physical and intellectual development. There is increasing evidence from many countries that that is the case. No avoidable condition claims more adult lives than tobacco addiction. As I have said, over two million people world-wide die each year from heart disease, lung cancer and emphysema caused by their addiction. Additional thousands die as a result of fires caused by cigarettes and from cancers caused by tobacco consumed as snuff or chewing tobacco. We must try to slow down this carnage in every possible way.

To give honourable senators some idea of the total lack of responsibility of the tobacco industry in this regard, it must be some three years ago that I suggested in this place by way of a question-it was well publicised at the time-that the Australian tobacco companies should consider devising, as can be devised quite simply, a self-extinguishing cigarette which, if it is dropped, left on the road or put down, will go out after a short period of time. Those hardened addicts from way back, including me, may recall the poverty of our youth when we rolled our own cigarettes. Most of them would go out if put down. Saltpetre and other chemicals are put into cigarettes to make them keep on burning. The point is that, if there were self-extinguishing cigarettes, we would not have fires caused by people smoking in bed. How often do we see in local papers that people are believed to have died because they were smoking in bed. When cigarettes are dropped, they should go out. I said at that time that I hoped that the tobacco industry in Australia had sufficient sense of responsibility to be self-regulating in this regard. But not a bit of it; no, it does not care whether people go on dying from fires caused by cigarettes. That is a matter of total lack of interest to the tobacco industry. That is a gross indictment of it.

One could go along these depressing themes for a long time, but I do not propose to do that. We have a long list of speakers and I am looking forward to hearing some of them. I want the Government to take seriously the suggestion that this Bill ought to be passed. It ought to go through its second reading and be considered by the Senate properly and reasonably as a piece of legislation that is important and urgent, in spite of all the other considerations that we have. I would like the Government to have courage and not to worry too much about the tobacco lobby, tobacco revenues and things like that. It should see that this is something that we cannot duck out on. It is something that we have to do something about. It was brought forward by the Australian Democrats in that interest and on that basis. The only responsible action that the Senate can take is to pass this Bill with as much speed as possible and so gain the long-lasting and unqualified support and respect of the Australian community. On that basis I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberal Party of Australia shares the concern of the Australian Democrats that there may be-may be-a health risk, as yet to be totally established, that emerges from smoking in aircraft. It is also concerned with the general issue of smoking in public transport. However, we do not share the Australian Democrats' solution to any problems that may-I underline the word `may'-emerge in health terms. We take the view that the Democrats' Bill, the Air Navigation (Smoking) Amendment Bill 1987, is therefore unsupportable in its present form.
—You can amend it if you like.

—Its form is so difficult that any amendment to make it acceptable would involve total rewriting and resubmission of it. That is a matter that should properly be the concern of the Government. I will return to that issue very shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me outline the serious problems that this Bill presents to the Senate. In effect, it provides that people can be sent to gaol for six months as a result of their smoking. That is an arrant nonsense and I think very few senators, no matter how violently they are opposed to smoking, would be prepared to accept that kind of proposition. It is a self-evident nonsense. I read from the Bill. Proposed new section 26 (a) (1) states:
A person shall not smoke in any part of an aircraft other than an enclosed space designated in accordance with the regulations as a smoking bay.
Penalty: $5,000 or imprisonment for 6 months.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a matter which I agree is necessary to be amended. I do not want Senator Button to suffer unnecessarily.

—Unlike the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, I am a non-smoker and would not face the risk of imprisonment and therefore deprive the Senate of the pleasure of my company by going into the cooler for six months as a result of my smoking.
—You could visit, Senator-not that I would encourage it, but you could.
—I think I would have better things to do. The second paragraph of the proposed new section states:

SPEECH.PARA: A space in an aircraft designated as a smoking bay shall be ventilated in such a way that it is not possible for smoke in the air in the space to enter the air in any other part of the aircraft.

Of course, the reality of that is to prohibit smoking on every aircraft in service in Australia. It would impose a massive cost burden in the sense of requiring the introduction of a separate ventilation system in all new aircraft coming into Australia-at significant expense, which would, of course, be borne by air travellers in Australia. I suggest that this Bill is an effective prohibition on smoking in aircraft with a penalty of up to six months gaol.

The Bill goes further. It does not relate simply to smoking in aircraft. It also relates to smoking in any part of an aerodrome other than a room designated in accordance with the regulations as a smoking room. Once again, a smoking room has to have a discrete ventilation system under the proposals, and it seems to the Liberal Party at least that this is taking matters to an extreme situation, particularly as aerodromes, and waiting rooms in aerodromes, are not confined spaces where people are obliged to spend lengthy amounts of time-except, I suppose, in cases of emergency-as is the case in an aircraft.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about check-in queues?
—As Senator Coates says, there are check-in queues. If the airlines take the view that the convenience of their passengers would be better served by prohibiting smoking in some areas, that is fine.

SPEECH.PARA: That brings me to the next point, which it seems to me is a significant one. There has already been a significant trend within the airline industry towards limiting the extent to which air travellers who are not smokers are inconvenienced by those who are. I think it is self-evident, particularly from the experience of Qantas Airways Ltd, which has probably been leading the way, quite apart from with what has been happening with the two major domestic airlines, that significant steps have been taken down the path of limiting the scope for smokers in aircraft. This, of course, is a response to commercial demand. I think we have to recognise this as a proper and sensible way for the airlines to go.

The airlines have been progressing in this direction. In fact, a couple of airlines in Australia, of their own volition, have banned smoking in aircraft. I presume that those of us who are not smokers and who find it unpleasant to breathe cigarette smoke would commend those airlines. Kendell Airlines is one of them, as is East-West Airlines Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Eastern.

—Eastern Airlines, as the honourable senator says, is also one of them. I understand that other airlines are at present considering that move-considering it, I might say, without the threat of the sort of legislation that Senator Mason and Senator Vigor want to impose on the nation, involving a penalty of six months in gaol. Nonetheless, there is a problem, which I recognise. This problem emerges from the Government's failure to proceed as it undertook to do last December. At that time the Minister for Aviation, Mr Peter Morris, announced that he would introduce legislation prohibiting smoking on domestic flights of less than 90 minutes. This, apparently, was in line with the Australian Labor Party's health platform adopted at the 1986 Conference, which called on the Government to:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . further restrict smoking on public transport, including domestic aircraft, and restrict smoking in public places to defined zones.
As Senator Vigor pointed out when introducing his Bill, the expectation was that the Government would act on that statement of last December. Now we are into May and nothing has happened.

TALK.START.PARA: —In our Bill it has happened.

—Nothing has happened on the part of the Government. It is all very well for Senator Powell. Because the Government has not introduced what may well be a sensible Bill-we do not know because we have not seen it-because the Government has not done what it undertook to do, there is no justification for the Senate accepting what is in fact a darned silly Bill which does not do the right thing and which attacks the problem in totally the wrong way. The Liberal Party takes the strong view that it would like to see the colour of the Government's legislation. The Government's failure to do anything about the matter perhaps shows that its Bill was stillborn. In that case it may well be yet another victim of smoking in labour. No doubt Senator Vigor, as an incipient parent once again, will have a special interest in that analogy. The reality is that Senator Vigor's Bill, as the honourable senator has pointed out, has at least drawn the Senate's attention to the fact that the Government has done nothing. As I said, whether or not the Opposition will support or oppose the Government's Bill, if and when it reaches this chamber, is a matter which will depend on the quality of that Bill. We are unaware of what that will be but we will hold our fire until we see it.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the demand for non-smoking seats in aircraft has increased significantly. On some flights, as Senator Vigor, I think, pointed out, something like nine out of 10 seats are now occupied by non-smokers. It has been suggested that one of the ways to discourage smokers from smoking even on those flights and to ensure that those who wanted a smoke-free flight could have one would be to encourage all non-smokers to get to terminals early to book all the smoking seats and then, of course, not smoke. The plane would then subtly be smoke free.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be recorded as a demand for smoking.

—As Senator Coates quite rightly says, that could then be recorded as a demand for smoking. It is one of those short term solutions which may not result in long term satisfaction. The reality is that when the Government announced that it would do something about smoking, at least on short flights, there was widespread support for that view. I think even the airlines indicated that they would welcome such a move. We have to recognise that the airlines face very substantial expenses in terms of cleaning the filters on their ventilation systems. To them it is an inconvenience. I presume that they provide smoking seats because they perceive that there is a demand for those seats. If Senator Vigor's Bill encourages strong expressions of public view which have an impact on the airlines themselves, of course it has an advantage. Those of us who do not like breathing secondhand smoke hope that this will take place. Whether it will take place by direction is a question that the Government itself has to address.

SPEECH.PARA: It has been suggested that the airlines have been holding back from progressing down that track in the expectation that the Government would provide legislation to force them to do what they really want to do themselves. If that is so, it is one of those examples of the prospect of legislation defeating, if you like, or delaying the ultimate good to the people concerned. It may well be, and I have heard it suggested quite strongly, that the airlines would be quite happy to have the responsibility for banning smoking on aircraft taken from them and placed firmly with the Government. That, of course, is a political issue that the Government has to face up to. I do not deny in any way that there are problems involved in smoking in aircraft, and I think very few people on this side of the chamber, even those who smoke, would do so.

Senator Vigor has pointed to the findings of the Committee on Airliner Cabin Air Quality, which reported to the Congress and which suggested a ban on smoking on all domestic flights. It also concluded that environmental tobacco smoke:
. . . is a hazardous substance and is the most frequent source of complaint about aircraft air quality.

In Australia there have been similar findings. The Occupational Health and Safety Study of In-flight Duties, commissioned by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines and referred to by Senator Vigor, has formed part of an industrial decision with the Australian Flight Attendants Association which, I understand, has resulted in an extra six days sick leave being made available to members of that organisation because of the emergency of upper respiratory tract problems resulting from air problems within aircraft-not necessarily all of them due, I might say, to cigarette smoking but nonetheless problems in which cigarette smoke is a major factor. The report said:

The only matter of significance found during the study concerned the quality of the air breathed during the flight and of the presence of contaminants likely to impair performance, health and . . . safety. The dominating factor--
not the only factor-
was cigarette smoke.
The report concluded:

We recommend that operators seriously consider a joint agreement to curtail the use of tobacco on all flights of less than 60 minutes duration as an intermediate step towards the eventual complete restriction of smoking on aircraft.

The recommendation was that the airlines should do so of their own volition. An encouragement to proceed in that direction would be appropriate. Whether we encourage the airlines to do so by legislative or other means is something to which the Government must address itself. It cannot keep ducking behind a statement that it intends to do something and then do nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would we have your support?

—Let us see what the legislation is like, Senator. We cannot stay in a vacuum such as this, which has already lasted six months, and be expected to take the Government seriously. The Government is being wimpish on this issue. It should make up its mind what it intends to do. We will happily look at its legislation. The point has been made, and I expect it will be made by other speakers on this side of the chamber, that the legislation, which we understand is still in gestation with the Government, limits the proposed prohibition on smoking to short flights. Yet, it has been pointed out that tobacco smoke on long flights creates an even worse pollutant. No doubt we will be able to consider that issue when we see what the Government's legislation is-if it comes forward.

SPEECH.PARA: I reinforce the point made by Senator Vigor that there is a respectable body of opinion that says that smoking in a passive sense creates some problems. However, I would rather see much more convincing conclusions from more detailed studies than we have had so far on the impact of passive smoking in enclosed spaces such as aircraft. I share Senator Vigor's concern based on a letter to honourable senators from the National Heart Foundation of Australia which spoke of:
. . . proper policies to protect smokers and non-smokers and improve general health and working conditions as restrictive smoking in the work place and other public places.

That is a matter which we, as legislators, should address. The National Heart Foundation expressed its concern in the letter about the effects of smoking, both active and passive, on the community. It said that smoking, without saying whether it was active or passive, was the major avoidable risk factor for cardiovascular disease, chronic lung disease and several important and fatal cancers. It said:

Passive smoking increases the risks of serious harm, such as lung infections in young children, lung infections in children and adults, lung cancer, and a worsening of health in those with existing heart and lung disease. Although active smoking is by far the greater concern, passive smoking is an important public health issue in its own right. Furthermore, passive smoking is not a matter of choice in most instances, and often occurs against the expressed wishes of the non-smoker.

In aircraft the big issue is the extent to which one becomes a passive smoker if one is in a non-smoking area. It is claimed that one is a passive smoker if one is in a non-smoking area. To my knowledge, no individual and substantial research has been done to establish that is the case for passengers in aircraft. It has been established that for flight stewards there is an impact because the level at which they work, which is higher than the level of seated passengers, has been established to be more contaminated. As I understand it, that fact was established in the study. However, as I understand that study, there has been no detailed work on the effect on the health of passengers in an aircraft which, for example, has 10 per cent smoking seats and 90 per cent non-smoking seats. If that work has not been done, I ask whether there is some benefit in doing it before imposing controls. On the basis of some of the information available, it would seem that there may be a risk. All I am saying is that, before going down the path of legislative action, would it not be proper to do some thorough examination of that risk? Is that not what responsible government is all about-examining what the risk is before rushing into legislation and putting people in gaol for six months.

It is hard to take seriously, if I may say so, a Bill which addresses a very serious question in such a reckless way. I would expect the airlines to come under increasing pressure from the people who are most affected by the problem-that is, the airline flight attendants who must put up with what they consider to be, and what a study has shown to be, an unpleasant atmosphere. The National Health and Medical Research Council has stated that an atmosphere free of tobacco smoke should be regarded as the work place norm and that employers should be reminded of their obligations to provide a safe working environment.

That seems to me to encompass the sorts of problems we face with this serious issue. I am not diminishing in any way the view of the Australian Democrats that it is a serious problem. I am seriously questioning the sense of bringing in a Bill that is draconian and involves, if it is to proceed, massive expenditure on the airlines to provide what may well be very little benefit ultimately, depending on whether there is a serious risk. The Bill de facto prohibits smoking on aircraft, because of the expense involved in providing the alternative that the Democrats claim is all they are seeking. That extends, quite irrationally in my view, to aerodromes.

While Senator Vigor's direction may well be an acceptable one which has widespread support in Australia-that is evident from the fact that the airlines have been going down that track-the reality is that the manner in which the Democrats propose to go about this seems to be authoritarian and offensive. The penalties are excessive. A Big Brother approach is clearly evident from the penalty of a $5,000 fine or six months imprisonment. I hope that there are better ways of resolving this threat once we establish its extent. Maybe the Government will tell that to us. It clearly has a duty to do so, following the introduction of the Democrats' Bill. They have pointed out the delay and the prevarication by the Government on this issue. Whilst all that is accurate, it is clear that Senator Vigor's Bill is not the right way to solve the problem, and the Opposition will not be supporting it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Air Navigation (Smoking) Amendment Bill 1987, submitted by the Australian Democrats with the view of persuading the Parliament to enact legislation that would drastically alter the existing arrangements in regard to smoking in civil aircraft and airports. One of the few privileges that honourable senators have is to move private members' Bills on the Thursday afternoon of a sitting week. The Government does not quarrel with that privilege that exists in our Standing Orders. Senator Vigor has taken advantage of that privilege to try to hasten the process by which government or private initiatives can realise the objective-this appears to be the basis of Senator Michael Baume's contribution-of eliminating, either in a voluntary or legislative way, smoking in public places.

SPEECH.PARA: We have to recognise that there has been a major evolution in community attitudes towards smoking in the last 20 years. What was once accepted as the norm is now recognised as constituting a major health hazard. I well recall in my very first year in the Senate, 1971, debates about what sort of warning was to be placed on cigarette packages; whether we would put that smoking was a health hazard, which was the compromise proposal of the then Government, to which Senator Baume belonged-I think he was then a member of the House of Representatives. That was the warning that the Minister for Health at that time was pursuing, whereas my party wanted to go further and express the view that smoking was more than just a health hazard, that it was, in fact, a process by which people's health was very dramatically affected.

We are dealing with a centuries' old habit. In the evolution of time we have seen dramatic changes in the way in which the community now perceives the problem of smoking in public places. Of course, that is to be welcomed. I represent in this place the Minister for Aviation (Mr Peter Morris). We have to concede that the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) also has a very active interest in this portfolio issue, as indeed do I, as the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I have to deal with the end product in my repatriation hospitals system. The Minister for Finance and Minister assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters (Senator Walsh) also has an interest. We cannot accept-I reject what Senator Michael Baume said on this-that the Government is entitled to be criticised when we look at what has happened recently. The Government has not resiled from its responsibilities in Public Service offices for example. The Government has thrown its weight behind the proposal to ban smoking in public places. In relation to passive smoking it has determined that those who wish to smoke in the Public Service environment shall do so in specially selected areas. It has thrown the initiative upon the smoker rather than the non-smoker.

One cannot say that the Government has not adopted a judicious, fair and reasonable approach to this matter. I think Senator Baume would be the first to acknowledge that within the last week or 10 days Telecom Australia, one of the public instrumentalities, has also moved down the track of putting the smoker on the defensive in the working environment. The Government accepts its national responsibility in this health matter. The way in which it prefers to move is to continue the evolution of understanding within the community so that we do not have to set up a punitive process by which those who enjoy the habit are placed in such a position as to be denied the opportunity to continue their habit, access to seats on aeroplanes and other forms of public transport, and the opportunity to work in public places.

It is in that environment that the Government says does not quarrel with the Democrats' motivation or their end objective. But we have some doubts about whether the legislation proposed by the Democrats is the path to take. I suppose to that extent we take a position closer to that taken by the Opposition, which prefers to have an emphasis on self-regulation rather than regulation. Senator Michael Baume is correct in referring to the early initiatives taken by the airlines, with at first only a few seats being set aside for non-smokers, whereas now the majority of seats are set aside. That is the process which the Government prefers.

One of the reasons I have exercised the opportunity to speak early in the debate is to express the Government's views in these matters; not so much to quarrel with the strategy that has been developed by the Democrats, but to indicate that we prefer the initiative to rest with the community and the airline industry itself. One of the great difficulties that the Government is confronted with in these matters is the effect of smoking on staff working in the aircraft. Senator Michael Baume is quite right in drawing attention to this. But in response to Senator Baume's criticism I refer to the experience that I have had in my portfolio responsibility. For example, in cases of lung cancer in veterans, who began smoking 40 years ago, I have had to ask what was the causal relationship. Only over time can we estimate the effect on air hostesses or hosts-we now have males working on many of our domestic and international flights-of passengers smoking. The smoke is at a high level and will affect the staff more than the passengers. We have to reach a conclusion whether, because of that, hostesses and hosts in their twenties or thirties will be affected in their fifties or sixties. This is the experience I have had in the Veterans' Affairs portfolio. People have begun smoking in their teens but it has not affected their basic health until later in their lives.

We believe that the initiative that has been suggested by the Democrats is unworkable. Some of the reasons for that have been referred to by Senator Michael Baume. There are flaws in the Bill. We have suggested to the Democrats that whilst they have the right to ventilate this issue and discuss it, there are problems relating to the ventilation in airports and on planes; and how to implement a smoking ban in a non-punitive way which is acceptable to the community, the airlines and the passengers, and which will not drastically infringe upon the rights of smokers who find great difficulty in taking the essential step to improve their health, that is by not smoking. What has the Government's position been in this matter? First of all, the Government's political position in the sense of its responsibilities to the platform of our Party is that it will seek to limit smoking in public transport, including domestic airlines. In other words, that is a persuasive approach rather than a regulatory approach. We recognise that there are tremendous public health cost implications in people smoking. I personally do not have any quarrel with that conclusion. To the extent that the community as a whole smokes and has done so over time, there must be cost implications in the public health area, as well as the private health area for that matter, because we have to deal with the end result, a person's state of health.

As an individual I am certainly convinced by the powerful argument from the National Heart Foundation and from medical specialists that lung disease and other diseases can be attributed to smoking. They have made those statements over a number of years. For example, my wife worked for some years as a librarian for the Australian Medical Association. She became convinced, just by cataloguing the evidence that was available-I am going back now 15 or 20 years-of how undesirable it was for people to smoke. What has emerged in the last half a dozen years is the acceptance not only that is smoking detrimental to an individual's health, but also that passive smoking is detrimental to health. That is a matter that has been identified by the medical profession, as well as by concerned citizens. They have made that point so vociferously-and very correctly in my view-that Parliament can no longer ignore the need for consideration of the issues.

The quarrel we have with the Australian Democrats is that the legislation could not realise its objectives, for a whole number of technical reasons, but we also believe that at this stage it is premature for the Government to go further down the track than it has in respect of its own employees. It has to live with the results of that innovation and its initiatives in the public sector. I imagine that there will be moves over time for the same sorts of initiatives to be taken in private sector employment. Moves will be made in stores, factories and offices to ensure that the non-smoker is protected and that the smoker is put on the defensive, which is quite contrary to what has been the long established position.

We have to recognise that there are rights which have to be protected. I suppose that is why we have been put in a position of having to defend what Senator Michael Baume says is neglect. I do not think that the Government has neglected its responsibilities in this area. I think there is a recognition of the complexities of the problem. This matter has been dealt with at Cabinet level. The Government has accepted the basic principles in these matters, but has placed the responsibility upon the airlines to respond. The airlines, being in competition with one another, are afraid to take the next step. That is the only conclusion that I can reach on the briefing notes that have been supplied to me.

The Government's view is that it is reasonable and responsible to say that smoking should be barred on domestic flights of less than 90 minutes. That is an issue on which we can probably reach some agreement. At the moment the Government's responsibility in providing legislation is based purely on the issue of safety. It is limited to that issue. Smoking does not constitute a safety issue on the aircraft, except during take-off and landing. Existing legislation covers smoking only during take-off and landing. In other words, if we are to move to the next stage, obviously new legislation is required.

The Cabinet has authorised legislation for a ban on smoking on receipt of a request from the major domestic airlines. So rather than the Government having to defend its position, I think the airlines have to take the next step. They have, for their own reasons, not been prepared to make the necessary request. This is despite the fact that the private airline Ansett Airlines of Australia has already imposed a ban on its coaches. In the majority of cases, coach trips would be longer than 90 minutes. So it has taken that tentative step, but it is not prepared to take the next step.

The Senate should be aware that the matter was raised during a meeting of the Aviation Industry Advisory Council as early as the beginning of 1986. The airlines indicated that they would accept a ban, but they considered that a legal instruction under the Air Navigation Regulations was required for enforcement. In a certain sense, we have reached an impasse. The airlines want to ban smoking, but they are not prepared to; and the Government wants to ban smoking, but it is not prepared to. That seems to me to be the position in which we find ourselves.

I remind the Senate that I have had several questions asked of me as the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. I have indicated the views of the Minister for Aviation. Recognising his public responsibilities, he has taken a submission to Cabinet and Cabinet has approved legislation subject to the receipt of requests from the major domestic airlines. In response to that decision the airlines say that this is a matter for the Government to determine. I find this a bit contradictory. I think one is entitled to say that many of the people associated with Ansett would take the view that government intervention and government involvement ought to be restricted. When it comes to the application of legislation dealing with this particular problem, the airlines have a stand-off position. The Government is in the invidious position where the airline's ideological position has not been brought out in the way it has approached this matter.

One can say: `What about the government airline?' The Senate will be aware that Australian Airlines is a statutory authority and it makes its own commercial decisions. But in this case it is not prepared to do so. This is in light of the fact that East-West Airlines Ltd, which is trying to become one of the big airline developers in our country, has expressed the wish to institute a smoking ban not just on the short hauls, but on all domestic flights. What should be the next step? That is a dilemma which this Government faces. Should there be a change of government the next Government will face this problem.

What is the next step? Accepting that there is a need to protect passengers from passive smoking and that there is a need to educate the community still further about the health hazards, the Government says: `We have made our decision. Now it is entirely up to the airlines to take it to the next stage'. If they are prepared to take that step, we are prepared to amend the legislation to meet the requirements. As I said, Ansett Pioneer Services has banned smoking on express coaches between Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane. It has done so because of public demand. Senator Michael Baume is quite correct in drawing attention to the fact that there has been a great increase in the number of seats that are provided for the non-smoker. Public demand has moved in the other direction to protect the non-smoker. That is part of the persuasion, the evolution, the process upon which the Government is relying. We all have our personal views on the matter. My office, bar one person, is a smoke-free zone. My electorate office is a smoke-free-zone. Public servants have different attitudes to the decisions the Government made with respect to the environment in which public servants work.

On 20 March this year, a little over six weeks ago, the Minister for Health wrote to the general-managers of both Ansett and Australian Airlines suggesting that they get together in an effort to reach an agreed position on the need for the early introduction of non-smoking flights of less than 90 minutes duration. So it is fair to say that the Government is not abrogating its responsibilities. The Government has been reasonable. It has said: `We are prepared to move but it has to be done on the basis of an agreed position with the airline industry'. The competitive influence which used to exist, and which still may be a major influence on this matter, is back in the airlines' corner.

Dr Blewett, the Minister for Health, has a major interest in this area, having regard to Medicare and the cost implications that flow from ill health arising from smoking. In responding to Dr Blewett, Australian Airlines said-I suppose that it is entitled to make its views known to the Minister for Health-that there is no clear legal basis for an airline to ban smoking. It said that where governments have considered a ban on smoking to be appropriate on other forms of transport or in public places, enabling legislation has been passed without requests from the parties affected. That is the view Australian Airlines has expressed. The Government maintains that is a view Australian Airlines is entitled to hold, but questions whether it indicates a willingness to comply with and implement any legislation the Government may bring forward should it be Government policy to act on the basis of the balance of interests involved.

I am expressing only a personal view, but maybe this issue should be determined by a non-party vote. I can imagine the difficulties that would exist in any party room if legislation were brought forward by any party against smoking. Smokers on my side of the chamber would have difficulty with that and I imagine that Senator Michael Baume would have the same problem. The problem would transcend party politics. It is not easy to take a decision about this matter. One would find that the different factions would have different views. The different ideologues who exist in the political process would fight to their last breath to protect their particular vested interests in this matter. Senator Powell is attempting to interject. The Democrats are lucky. There are only a few of them and maybe they are all non-smokers. I can assure them that that is not the position in my Party and I am certain that it is not the position in the other political parties. If there is to be progress in this area of legislation, somewhere along the line it may have to be dealt with at a different level. It will not be very helpful if by 61 votes to 59 a Caucus or a parliamentary group of any of the major parties forces the issue to that extent. We have to admit that there has been a measurable increase in public awareness. There has been an increased acceptance that change needs to be effected in this area. The Government is inclined to rely upon that process rather than the processes Senator Vigor has suggested.

In the period of the previous Government, in 1982, the Department of Aviation introduced a policy of providing non-smoking seats within public areas in airport terminal buildings. These areas are still being established progressively at all Commonwealth airports. The Department also requires the provision of non-smoking areas in all new airport terminals. Depending upon one's personal approach, this represents progress with respect to the smoking issue. During the same period the possibility of providing separate air conditioned smokers' lounges was considered but rejected due to the high costs and difficulties foreseen in policing such areas. Consideration was also given to having separate air-conditioning units in aircraft. That is an example of what renders Senator Vigor's proposal unacceptable to the Government. Technically there would have to be two different units in the one aircraft. A cost factor is involved. As Senator Michael Baume correctly suggested, there would have to be a regulatory process which would involve more and more people supervising the legislation. Many factors have to be considered, without in any way taking away the right of Senator Vigor and the Democrats to put forward their proposals.

The Bill we are considering excludes private and public aerodromes from coverage. It specifies `only those aerodromes established under the Air Navigation Regulations Nos 82, 84 and 85'. We accept that this is probably consistent with the Commonwealth's powers. However, it appears that the Bill would provide a smoking ban in all parts of an aerodrome except a room designated for the purpose and would include open spaces within the boundaries of the aerodrome, its carpark and so on. The Bill has widespread implications, therefore, which cannot just be written off by the passage of private member's legislation. We have no quarrel with the right of the member, but we do quarrel with the precise terms of the legislation which, whilst the Government accepts it may have a motivation towards improving public health, is not realisable in the short term. Senator Vigor's Bill would hasten the application of a ban on smoking in such a way as to create a whole number of technical and legal difficulties.

We suggest to the Democrats that they ultimately withdraw the proposal on the understanding that the Government will examine the Bill and take further steps and initiatives, in conjunction with the airline industry, to see whether it is possible to come up with a formula which would realise the objectives put forward by the supporters of the legislation, with goodwill and with good intentions, but which would also protect the general public and those who want to smoke. I am sure that the honourable senators on my side of the chamber who smoke do not want to place me, as a non-smoker, at any disadvantage. Similarly, as a non-smoker I must consider whether I want to put them at a disadvantage. We can surely work out a compromise. It is within the means of advanced civilisation to come up with a formula which will protect all the interests concerned. We do not believe, therefore, that the legislation suggested by Senator Vigor should be supported.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Air Navigation (Smoking) Amendment Bill 1987 brought before the Senate as a private member's Bill by my colleague Senator Vigor. I confess at this early stage to having the zeal of a convert, as was also confessed by Senator Mason before me. I pay tribute to and thank my children who are responsible for my conversion, and perhaps before them to their teachers in the public education system, the National Heart Foundation, the anti-cancer councils and all those good people who are working to make people like me see the light when there is still time to redress the damage. I am reassured that our bodies cells are replaced once every seven years. Thus, since I gave up smoking I have had at least three new bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: I appreciate the perceived needs of people who, as I think the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) said, have a habit, having been one of those people at one stage of my life. I also accept the evidence, which is now clear and on the public record, which shows us that there are dangers not just to people who are smokers but also to people who come within range of people smoking-passive smokers-who inhale sidestream smoke and for whom a smoke free environment is really the only safe environment.

Senator Michael Baume, speaking for the Liberal Party in this debate, seemed to indicate that we should wait for the Government to act on what is, after all, Australian Labor Party policy. I do not believe that is a particularly strong argument. I am sure that a great many members of the once great ALP would agree with me that if we sat on our hands and waited for this Hawke Government to implement Labor Party policy we would have a long wait.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good point.

—I thank the honourable senator. I think this can be illustrated by a litany of policies which have been duly adopted at ALP conferences. Senator Baume outlined the ALP anti-smoking and smoke free air policy, which I endorse. I refer to other ALP policies which it has adopted through its relatively democratic policy-making process. It pales into insignificance against the Australian Democrats policy-making process. Nevertheless, ALP policies are not brought into being by this ALP Hawke Government. I refer to policies which guarantee a safer and healthier future, such as the anti-nuclear policy. We are told by medical experts around the world that nuclear weapons are very strongly medically contra-indicated. That is another health policy of the ALP which we are not seeing implemented by this Government. I could list a great many policies which have not been implemented. I thought the ALP believed education was a right and not a privilege. Of course, there are hundreds of thousands of students around Australia at the moment who are feeling disillusioned about the non-implementation of that policy. Many pensioners are moving around this city and this building at the moment--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I think the honourable senator is straying quite a way from the subject matter of the Bill that is before the chamber at the moment and I ask you to bring her to order.
—Senator Powell, I draw your attention to the character of the motion and the Bill.

—As I said, Mr Acting Deputy President, I speak with the zeal of a convert and, in relating my remarks to Senator Baume's earlier remarks, I have had brought to mind a great many issues which may be somewhat peripheral. I certainly appreciate your guidance in this matter. Senator Baume and the Minister have suggested that we should also wait for the airlines to act in this matter. The Minister was quite adamant on that point. I think it just takes a little thinking to reason out why that is not a tenable position and not a position which will get us smoke free air on aircraft. Perhaps I will come to that matter a little later but I simply say at this stage that in the commercial world it is not a surprise to find that one airline will not implement a policy of no smoking on its aircraft unless it is guaranteed that the other airline is going to do it at the same time. Indeed, the opinion of Ansett Airlines of Australia was given to us by the Minister. It points out that there is a need for legislation for the airlines to bring in, even together, a smoking ban on aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: A great many points have been made and will, I am sure, be made about the reasons why smoking should be banned, particularly in aircraft. There is a high proportion of flammable materials on aircraft. The plastic linings, the upholstery and the materials which furnish the aircraft are flammable. Indeed, I have seen claims that it was suspected that at least two recent air disasters were caused by concealed burning cigarettes. My colleague, Senator Mason, spoke at some length about the virtues of a self-extinguishing cigarette. Perhaps we should bear this in mind when we think about that safety aspect.

It has been well documented that the costs to airlines, and therefore to passengers through the cost of tickets, of smoking on aircraft are very high. The cost of cleaning or replacing clogged air filters alone is about $500,000 a year for one airline. That does not take into account the burns on carpets and seats and the discolouration of walls which all have to be dealt with in the normal maintenance program. Major airlines have said at various times that they would be keen to have a ban on smoking on aircraft. As I have said, there is a need for the legislature to provide a leadership role and an enabling role in this exercise.

Airline staff have been pressing long and hard-formally since 1982-for this ban. They now warn of industrial action unless it is introduced. Some of us suffered because of industrial action, at least with one airline, in flying from Melbourne on Monday of this week. This Parliament should not wait until there is some form of industrial action on this issue. I think it is worth listening to people whose working lives are made unpleasant, if not miserable, by smoking. It should be banned, at least on short trips. Of course, if airline staff are not satisfied with the situation they might actually move against the airlines and claim for damages to their health. This will probably occur unless some sort of action is taken.

I turn to the situation overseas. The Government airline in Canada, Air Canada, has banned smoking on its major trunk routes, and those bans are being extended. The Swedish domestic airline has banned smoking on all its flights. The Soviet airline, Aeroflot, banned smoking on its domestic flights three years ago. The chief company doctor of the Swedish airline has pointed out-Senator Baume seemed to be indicating to us that maybe the cabin staff had a problem because they operate at a higher level than the passengers-that the atmosphere in the cabins of aircraft is drier and has a higher ozone level than normal air. I am referring to the whole cabin, not just where the cabin crew are working. He points out that while that, in itself, is not dangerous, it causes irritation to the mucous membranes and that problem is magnified by cigarette smoke.

The Swedish airline was probably motivated by research conducted by Aeroflot on its pilots, which showed that if they smoked even a single cigarette before a flight it would reduce their ability to adapt to darkness and discern colours. That, perhaps, extends the issue of smoking outside the flight time. The airlines, of course, favour smoke-free flights for many reasons-safety, which I have mentioned, economy, health and hygiene. There is a very strong case to be made. It is interesting that Sweden has chosen to promote its ban at the provision of smoke-free services. That is a positive approach, and is what we should do as we are trying to promote public health and safety.

More than 70 per cent of flights on airlines in Australia are now no-smoking because the smaller airlines have taken a no-smoking stand. Many flights are of less than 90 minutes duration-for example, from Melbourne to Sydney, Adelaide, Canberra, Albury, Hobart, Launceston, Devonport and so on. Cinemas and theatres are already smoke free because of fire regulations in all States. Surely what is possible in those public areas is also possible on aircraft. Public transport and a number of other confined areas, such as elevators, are also smoke free in most States. During the past 12 months many more work places have become smoke free-a large number of them voluntarily-and it is encouraging to note that change in community attitudes. This legislation is simply another step in that direction.

There is a specific problem in creating smoke-free zones on aircraft unless there is a smoking ban. As there is no effective barrier between the smoking and the no-smoking sections, the whole of the air becomes permeated and everyone on the plane is subjected to passive smoking. All airlines are reporting less and less demand for smoking seats. Indeed, many smokers choose to sit in no-smoking seats-although, as was said earlier, that can actually rebound on the move towards no-smoking. I think that something much more direct, such as legislation in this chamber, would be a much better idea than following a practice that distorts statistics. The reverse aspect is that non-smokers are often forced to sit in smoking areas because sufficient no-smoking seats are not available.

I have not yet put any emphasis on the evidence in the public arena about the dangers of smoking generally. During this and other debates in this chamber about smoking, that evidence has been well canvassed. It is for that reason that the United States Academy of Science has called for a ban, as has the United States National Research Council. The United States Congress currently has a proposal before it to ban smoking on flights of less than two hours duration, or on flights where no seating is assigned for non-smokers, and that covers many domestic flights in the United States. It was intriguing, and even a little worrying, that Senator Michael Baume, the health spokesperson for the Liberal Party of Australia, stressed so often in his contribution that he was not convinced by evidence in the community. He keeps calling for more detailed information, yet authorities such as those to which I referred have come out in favour of bans on the basis of the very detailed information that is now a matter of public record. I am concerned that someone in Senator Baume's position appears not to be prepared to accept that evidence.

New figures from the National Health and Medical Research Council show that an estimated 136 people each year die of lung cancer as a result of passive smoking. Those are not the people who, through free individual choice, have chosen to smoke; but those who have had no choice at all. There is strong and growing evidence that sidestream smoke is more harmful than the smoke inhaled through a cigarette. It contains a number of carcinogens, and in greater concentration than in smoke inhaled by the smoker. The Age and the Sydney Morning Herald on 12 April showed that 57 per cent of people support smoke-free aircraft, 62 per cent of whom are white collar workers. They are some of the most travelled people in the air, and among those travelling most often on domestic airline flights below 90 minutes duration are people who work in this place and travel back and forth to work, many of us on a weekly basis.

There is strong support in the community for this sort of legislation. We believe that the presentation of this private member's Bill by Senator Vigor makes a major contribution to the general debate. It is interesting to note that, in these stringent economic times, a particular exercise is affecting this issue. It has come to our notice that airline passengers are now getting less fresh air than they did 10 years ago because of the cost-cutting exercises by airlines. Ten years ago some 15 to 20 cubic feet of fresh air was generated through the cabin, but that is now down to about 7 cubic feet because the exercise requires a great deal of fuel. The airlines have cut back on the passage of fresh air to the cabin. Therefore, it is even more urgent that this Parliament takes some action.

There are additional issues in the whole area of the damage and costs to our community caused by addiction-which is what it is-to a legal drug. The evidence is disturbing, so any action that we can take, as a body of responsible people, will be responsible action. I am encouraged by the remarks of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. The Australian Democrats have initiated debate on a number of matters that Parliament has the ability to influence. Parliament can, perhaps, reduce the damage done by smoking to our community health. On every possible occasion, the Australian Democrats have taken the opportunity, as we are doing today, to face Parliament with its true responsibilities. They include the ability to impose a tax on cigarettes, which would put their price out of the reach of, for instance, young people, and decisions about whether advertisements of various kinds, in various places and at various times were appropriate. We have taken these opportunities, as we have with this legislation, not just because we are concerned that some people are choosing to engage in this activity. Our particular concern is that evidence is showing that young people are still inappropriately beginning to take up this habit. I do not think that even adult people for whom it is a matter of normal practice really want to see our young people take it up, yet this is continuing to happen.

The Parliament has a responsibility in a number of areas. The Australian Democrats have brought forward this legislation because we believe it is an opportunity for the Parliament to act in the interests of having a smoke-free zone for those people using our domestic airlines. We are encouraged to a certain extent by some of the comments made by Senator Gietzelt in this debate. We will continue to press not just for debate on this issue but for the Parliament to take action on this issue, which has a great effect on our public health. We believe that we have a responsibility as a Parliament to act wherever that is possible.
