SPEECH.PARA: I think that the question of smoking and non-smoking has also become a very trendy and popular issue on which to run. Indeed, I think that is the very reason why we are debating this Bill here today. A tremendous amount of government money and private money is being devoted to research on this one element of public health-the question of smoking and the dangers that arise from it both to the smoker and to the non-smoker. I was amazed at a release put out under the name of the National Health and Medical Research Council, I think earlier this week, relating to some unfortunate individual who had to sit-one imagines in a room with no windows and the air totally controlled-through 17 or so separate studies on smoking and come up with one hypothesis on the whole question of passive smoking and statistics on its effects. How would a person get any real job satisfaction from doing something like that? I suppose one would have to be provided with a computer to do it.

I think that because this issue is trendy it is receiving undue attention. People can identify an individual who smokes not only when the individual has a cigarette in his hand or his mouth but also by the smell which that individual exudes. At the end of the day, and sometimes even at the beginning of the day, the clothes smell, the hair smells and the hands smell. The room in which a smoker works smells. I know that from experience. I know that I am a polluter of the atmosphere. I apologise for it. I will try to give up the habit but, unfortunately, I do not think this week or next week is the time to start trying.

I wish to point out, however, one very great danger to us as legislators-and I refer to all parties. In looking at the question of public health we must be careful not to home in on one popular trendy issue. Too often-the medical profession is to blame here-when a person dies and the death is attributed to lung cancer we start searching back through the history of the poor, unfortunate corpse to find out whether that individual at some time smoked or lived with a smoker. If that is found to be the case, it is all too easy to state on the death certificate and to have it recorded in the relevant statistics that that death from lung cancer was attributed to smoking. I think far too little research goes into industry and the hazards that workers in industry have to endure. The same applies to the pollutants that members of the community have to endure. When we fly around this country, hopefully soon in aircraft that leave the air pure, we in turn are polluting the environment. Maybe one day that issue will become trendy and the Australian Democrats will flock into Canberra so that they will not have to travel, and really run hard with that issue.

On the question of smoking and occupational health and safety, very few doctors in this country particularly-and we are talking only about this country-are skilled in diagnosing the effects of industry on workers' health and safety. A lot of attention has been paid in recent years to the issue of asbestos, which was raised by the trade union movement with the help of some sympathetic medical persons.

TALK.START.PARA: —Back to the subject.
—I will get back to the subject.
—That was trendy years ago.

—It is still trendy. Did Senator Powell see in the news bulletins last week the number of people who died, and the number who continue to die, working for a particular company? People in my area of Wittenoom are continuing to die as a result of suffering from exposure to asbestos.
—What about the smokers?

—Has Senator Walters ever looked at the statistics on deaths attributed to smoking? It is a disgrace and an indictment on this society and us in this Parliament as legislators that we did not act earlier to do something about it. I agree with some of the comments about the action we should take in respect of smoking on aircraft. I will return to that topic.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party's policy in respect of smoking has been mentioned. Senator Gietzelt spelt that out very well. For the sake of time I will not elaborate on it because it is on the record and in our publications. I find that one of the quirks of nature at ALP conferences-I attend a few at both the State level and the national level-is that whilst we probably make our deliberations in halls as big as this chamber-in the case of the last National Conference in Hobart the hall was a lot larger than this chamber-the halls are declared a smoke free zone. At the beginning of the conference the delegates vote on the matter and declare the conference venue a smoke free zone. Subsequently, the poor, afflicted individuals like me and you, Mr Acting Deputy President, sneak out to the corridors and smoke there. After a few hours of heavy debate on all sorts of issues we sneak out yet again. Probably on the second, third or fourth occasion we do not even have to light a cigarette because the air in the confined space of the corridor is polluted. Let me just give the Senate an example to put what I have just said into some perspective. Because of the size of this chamber, we are not allowed to smoke in it, and I am not advocating that we should. But we are allowed to smoke in the tiny adjoining alcove, a confined space which holds the smoke. I know that, because I have walked through it myself.

As I said at the beginning of my remarks, we have before us a very draconian piece of legislation which will not solve the problem confronting us. We never will solve problems such as this by imposing penalties of the magnitude put forward-not even suggested-by Senator Vigor. Let me just repeat the penalties. For a person smoking on an aircraft, the penalty proposed is $5,000 or imprisonment for six months. The Bill provides for a penalty of $5,000 or imprisonment for six months for lighting a cigarette on an aircraft or in an area of a terminal which is designated as a non-smoking area.

TALK.START.PARA: —You get no more than that if you shoot your mother-in-law.

—Exactly. I ask: What competence can we attribute to the authors of this legislation if they resort to tactics such as that? As the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills has said, a very serious criminal offence must be involved if we are to consider penalties of that nature. We must look also at what smoking is. Senator Vigor was kind enough to give the Committee some thoughts on his definition by referring to a Bill that had previously been introduced in this chamber.
—If you don't hurry up Senator Elstob is not going to get a chance to say something, and he desperately wants to support you.
—I appreciate that he might run out of breath. I will wind up my remarks. I quote Senator Vigor:

SPEECH.PARA: For example, another Bill introduced into the Senate defines smoking as `the act of inhaling, exhaling, puffing, sucking or blowing the smoke of a tobacco product'.

But we also have problems in defining a tobacco product. If in this chamber I took out one of my cigarettes and, without putting it in my mouth, lit it and held it in my hand, would I be smoking or not? I will not ask the President, or even you, Mr Acting Deputy President, to rule on that point. I am slightly against it. I think there are other ways of doing it. I am not against the proposal put forward by the Government and by the airlines that bans on smoking be limited to flights of less than 90 minutes. I will endure and suffer that restriction. There are actually some nights in the week when I can sleep for more than two hours without waking up to have a cigarette. I urge the Senate, when voting on this legislation, if it gets to vote, to reject it. I think Senator Vigor will have earned some more names for himself in putting forward this piece of legislation. I would call him the Genghis Khan of clean air or perhaps the Joh Bjelke-Petersen of civil liberties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I know very well that you would dearly like to speak on this subject. I will be very quick just to give you a few minutes. I have found myself in complete agreement with Senator McKiernan, who preceded me, which probably makes him have another think as to whether he could possibly be right. I am a non-smoker. I have never smoked, which I find has been very fortunate. I did not take up smoking in my early years and, having watched some of my relatives going through the very traumatic experience of trying to give it up, I can only be thankful that I was not introduced to it when I was much younger.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has already said that it will be bringing in legislation which deals with smoking on airlines and I understand from Senator Gietzelt's speech that it will contain a provision banning smoking on short flights of 90 minutes or less. I find that completely illogical. If this ban is to be imposed on short flights because of the hazards of passive smoking what on earth is the damage done to people on long flights? The proposition is illogical. That is all I wish to say on that subject. I cannot understand how the Government could say that harm is caused to passive smokers on short flights when it allows smoking to continue on longer flights-for example, on a three-hour flight to Perth.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is recognising human weakness.

—Let us recognise the human weakness of people on short flights. Senator McKiernan says that he has to wake up every two hours to have a cigarette. It seems that we would be doing him a great disservice if ever he has to go to Perth again. I cannot understand why the Australian Democrats would not just shoot or hang those who did not comply with the legislation. It provides for a prison sentence of six months or $5,000 fine. Perhaps Senator Powell now understands the difference between `and' and `or'. If the penalty was a $5,000 fine and imprisonment-I would not have been surprised seeing the legislation is so draconian-she may have understood the difference between `and' and `or' in respect of the Equal Employment Opportunity (Commonwealth Authorities) Bill, because she could not see the difference when we debated it. However, in this legislation she can suddenly see the difference.

SPEECH.PARA: The imposition of such draconian penalties on a person who smokes in an aircraft or at an aerodrome in areas in which smoking is not permitted is quite ludicrous. We need to exercise a little tolerance. I understand that some non-smokers are allergic to smoking. They find that their eyes run and are very sore, and they object to the smell of smoke on their clothes. Nasal symptoms, coughing, wheezing and so on can result from passive smoking. However, let there be no doubt that passive smoking does cause problems. In 1977 I was a member of the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare of which Senator Peter Baume was the Chairman. The Committee produced a report entitled `Drug Problems in Australia-An Intoxicated Society'. The Committee considered tobacco smoking. The Committee's report states:

Evidence has indicated that, in confined atmospheres, passive smoking leads to absorption of carbon monoxide into the bloodstream of non-smokers, where it forms the compound carboxyhaemoglobin. Such passive smokers generally show above-average levels of this compound.
That was the evidence in 1977 when passive smoking was not a trendy subject. Other evidence which the Committee received was:

The most common effects experienced by non-smokers as a result of passive exposure include eye irritation, nasal symptoms, coughing and wheezing. Smokers should realise the discomfort-and at times distress-which their habit causes other people, and as a matter of courtesy regulate their smoking so as not to inconvenience anyone.

More serious consequences were shown to exist for children of `smoking families'. One survey of 1119 subjects recorded 33 per cent more respiratory disease in young children of `heavy smoking families' . . .
Importantly, the evidence continued:

A similar survey examined the incidence of pneumonia and bronchitis on 2205 young children over the first three years of life. Their respiratory symptoms and the parents' smoking habits were checked annually. In the first year of life, the incidence of pneumonia and bronchitis was lowest where both parents were non-smokers and highest where both smoked.

In the first year of life, and when a mother is breastfeeding her baby, there is a very close association between her and her baby. The survey showed that, after the first year of life, the consequences were negligible and were not conclusive in any way. That, I think, underlines the point made by Senator Michael Baume when he said that in very confined spaces, where there is a one to one association, harm is done. As has been indicated, the National Health and Medical Research Council came out with recommendations in 1975 and 1976 with which we, as a Committee, agreed. Those recommendations were:
(a) To prohibit smoking in hospitals and other health care institutions except in specially designated areas;
(b) To adopt regulations to protect non-smokers from exposure, without their consent, to tobacco smoke in the working environment;
(c) To provide or extend non-smoking areas in public transport and other public places where smoking is not totally prohibited--
such as restaurants, cafes and bars--
(d) To clearly define non-smoking areas in public transport and other places where smoking is not totally prohibited; and
(e) To give special attention to the protection of infants from contact with persons who are smoking.

That is as far as we should go. We should make areas available for those who wish to smoke. To penalise a smoker who dares to light up a cigarette in an aircraft or an aerodrome, other than in the correct areas, is beyond any reasonable acceptance of the individual's rights. In the last few minutes of this debate, I have pleasure in handing over to Senator Elstob.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Elstob Sen R.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Air Navigation (Smoking) Amendment Bill, which has been introduced by the Australian Democrats, is probably the most draconian legislation that has ever been brought before this Parliament. The wording of the legislation means that not only those who smoke on a commercial airliner would face a fine of $5,000 or a six-month prison sentence but also a person flying his own aircraft-there may be only one person in the aircraft; the pilot-who dared to smoke would also be liable to a fine of $5,000 or six months imprisonment. That is how foolish the legislation is. If the Democrats had wanted to improve the health of the Australian community I would have considered their proposition more seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that there should be a complete review of what we are doing. Many things are wrong in our community. I am nearly 63 years old and I have smoked for 50 years. However, I have never said that what is good for me is beneficial to someone else. I would not be so ridiculous as to say that. I am fortunate in having been born of healthy parents. I notice that I have 43 minutes in which to speak--

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Elstob, you are under a misapprehension. You do not have 43 minutes; you have until 5.43 p.m.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. There are many issues which I would like to touch on but, unfortunately, I do not have the time to do so. If we are to consider ways of improving our health, one of the first things that I would look at, as a person who has gained some experience in my 63 years, would be air-conditioning in public buildings. Air-conditioning is the most outrageous thing that has been inflicted on the human race. Because we want to utilise all the available space, when we build we do not allow for natural ventilation. In a country such as Australia, which has good air 95 per cent of the time, it is unnecessary to heat or to cool that air. We restrict the flow of air by bringing it in through an air-conditioner. In the early 1970s, when the price of fuel rose, the people who controlled the buildings restricted the air flow. It costs money to heat or to cool air, so we now find that only about 25 per cent of the air that we breathe in any public building is fresh. It has been proved beyond all doubt that air-conditioning is one of the great polluters of our time. Yet why is it that doctors and others, as Senator McKiernan said, find it trendy today to blame smoking. I do not believe that.

SPEECH.PARA: Many years ago I worked on the waterfront. At that time, when mechanisation took place, many people working down below in the ships' holds were suddenly dying-we thought from heart attacks. Over a period of 10 years we gathered many statistics on this and we proved beyond any doubt-this proof did not come from the medical profession, it came through our own research-that those people had suffered a build-up of carbon monoxide gases. We took that evidence to a convention in the United States of America, which proved that we were right. We were then able to insist that the machines had to be powered by liquefied petroleum gas, which is a much cleaner fuel than petrol. That stopped people dying from the build-up of carbon monoxide gases in their bodies. It was once believed that if people got out into fresh air all the carbon monoxide gases in their bodies would dissipate, but that is not so because the gases build up. People who thought that they were having heart trouble or that they had blood clots to the brain and similar things, found that they were suffering from a build-up of carbon monoxide gases. How many people in our community are affected in that way?

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to him. Would you like to stop for a cough?

—Senator, I have to work. I had never been ill in my life until 1985. I have gone through many trials and tribulations. I have scraped the bottom of barrels and I have licked the cream with the best. I have not been ill and I do not take many drugs. I am one of those people who like a cigarette but I have never been drunk in my life. I enjoy life. I think I have some feeling for my fellow human beings. Senator Janine Haines was on a plane with me once and she said `Would you mind not smoking as I suffer badly because of it?' so I said: `I will not smoke'. I consider other people's feelings and I think every person who smokes has some compassion for other people. But it is quite wrong for people to take this high attitude and say that smoking is the cause of all our ills. It is not.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to amend the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976, and for related purposes.
Bill presented by Senator Gareth Evans, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

When the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs introduced the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986 on 22 October last, he indicated that action on a number of matters had been deferred to allow more time for problems to be analysed and discussed. This Bill sets out the Government's proposals for a new regime to cover exploration and mining on Aboriginal land which is the first fruit of that further process of analysis and discussion.

Consultation with the various interested parties has been extensive. In particular, the Northern Territory land councils have been given many opportunities over the last two years to put their views to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, to the caucus committee on Aboriginal affairs, and to myself.

The Government has sought, to the maximum practicable extent, to accommodate the views of all parties. Where this has not been possible, best efforts notwithstanding, it has sought to follow a course that strikes a fair and equitable balance between competing interests, while preserving at all times the essential purpose of the Act-that is, enable Aboriginals in the Northern Territory to claim land of traditional significance, and to control activities undertaken on that land.

The amendments now being placed before the Parliament, together with those contained in the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1986, will significantly improve the operation of the Act in the key areas. By reducing the potential for continued tension and conflict between Aboriginals and non-Aboriginals in the Territory, the amendments will reinforce and strengthen the real and lasting benefits that Aboriginals in the Northern Territory have gained from this legislation.
I refer now to the main features of the Bill.
Exploration and Mining on Aboriginal Land

The single most controversial aspect of the Act over the last 5 years has been the set of provisions regulating the exploration for, and mining of, minerals and in particular, the operation of the mining veto on Aboriginal land.

However, it is fair to say that it has not been the existence of the veto power which has produced the present situation where only one agreement between Aboriginals and companies has been concluded under the Act since its enactment. Rather, the major reason is that the implicit conjunctive structure and direction of the Act tended to work against the finalisation of exploration licence applications and the resolution of disputes.
The new scheme embodied in this Bill recognises the need to clearly set out the rights and obligations of the councils and companies and requires them to work within a set of firm parameters.

The new scheme will ensure that Aboriginal traditional owners are able to control exploration and mining activity on their land. As well, it will allow those Aboriginals wishing to negotiate agreements with companies for the grant of exploration and mining interests to do so with greater certainty of the process and time limits within which those negotiations take place.

In summary, the new scheme will provide clear guidelines governing the granting of a once-only consent at the exploration stage and the negotiation of terms and conditions at the exploration and mining stages.
The Exploration Stage

A person who has the approval of the Northern Territory mining Minister will be able to apply to the relevant land council for its consent to the grant of an exploration licence. An applicant will be required, within certain time limits, to submit a detailed application to the land council, which will then have 12 months-and such further time as either the parties agree or the Minister allows-in which to give or refuse its consent and to come to an agreement in respect of the terms and conditions relating to the exploration proposal.

Within that period the land council will have to consult the traditional Aboriginal owners of the land and any Aboriginal community or group that may be affected by the grant of the exploration licence. The land council will be obliged to convene meetings with the traditional Aboriginal owners to consider the exploration proposals, and the applicant or his nominated representative will be able to attend such meetings to present and explain the exploration proposals. The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs will also be able to send a representative to such meetings.
The land council will be required to either consent, or refuse to consent, to the grant of an exploration licence in accordance with the wishes of the traditional Aboriginal owners.

In general, where consent is refused, no further exploration licence applications will be able to be made in relation to that land for 5 years. If, on the expiration of the 5-year period, the same applicant wished to present a further application he will be able to exercise that option. It has been decided, however, that a ministerial discretion to re-open the application process at the request of the relevant land councils should be retained for use in special circumstances. The use of this discretion will involve appropriate consultations with Commonwealth and Northern Territory Ministers and requires the Minister to be satisfied that the re-opening of the application is, among other things, in the public interest. This provision is not intended as a backdoor means by which Aboriginals can avoid the necessary incentive to seriously consider the ramifications of any decision to refuse consent.

If a land council has neither consented nor refused to consent at the end of the 12 months, consent shall be deemed to have been given by the land council. So that this deeming provision does not operate unfairly in situations where, for example, there is a sizable backlog of applications, the Bill makes provision for a land council to apply to the Minister for an extension beyond 12 months.

A decision by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs to extend the negotiating period requires consultation with the Northern Territory mining Minister. Further, the Minister must be satisfied that in all the circumstances it is not reasonably practicable for the land council to perform these functions within the normal period. The Minister must also give written notice of his decision to the applicant, the land council and the Northern Territory mining Minister.
Where a land council consents, or is deemed to have consented, to the grant of an exploration licence the Minister will also have to consent before the licence can be granted.

Where there is no agreement on terms and conditions within the negotiating period, the parties may either agree to appoint a person to conciliate or may request the Minister to refer for conciliation the matters in dispute to a person appointed as a mining commissioner.

Upon the expiry of the negotiating period, and the consequent deeming of consent in the absence of express refusal, the Minister shall appoint a mining commissioner who shall attempt to conciliate between the parties concerning the matters in dispute. Where such conciliation is unsuccessful the mining commissioner shall proceed, by arbitration of the matters in dispute, to determine the terms and conditions which he considers should be acceptable to both parties.

In determining the terms and conditions of exploration the mining commissioner shall have regard to a number of specific matters, relating to the impact of exploration on Aboriginal land and on the lifestyle, culture and traditions of the Aboriginals.

The terms and conditions either agreed between the parties or determined by the mining commissioner may include the payment of compensation for damage or disturbance caused to Aboriginal land but shall not include compensation for the value of minerals removed or proposed to be removed from the ground and shall not include payments for any other purpose, for example, payment which is not related to damage or disturbance but is made simply in return for the giving of consent to the application.

Where the intending explorer is willing to enter into an agreement on the terms and conditions determined by the mining commissioner then the land council shall enter into an agreement on those terms and conditions.

The Bill contains a safeguard clause which empowers the Minister, after consultancy with the Northern Territory mines Minister, to cancel an exploration licence or lease if he is satisfied that the actual exploration activity does not accord with the proposal and that consent would not have been given. He must also be satisfied that the national interest does not require that the exploration works proceed.
The Mining Stage

The central feature of the Bill as it relates to the mining stage is that a further consent is not required to enable the successful explorer to proceed to develop a mineral deposit. It is necessary however that a terms and conditions agreement be entered into by the parties and be approved by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs before a mining licence can be granted by the Northern Territory Minister for Mines.

The intending miner will have to submit to the land council a written statement setting out a full range of specified particulars concerning the proposed mining activity and its impact on Aboriginal land and on Aboriginal people.

The parties will have 12 months, or such longer time as they agree, within which to endeavour to reach agreement. As at the exploration stage, the Bill requires land councils to consult with traditional owners and other affected persons, and to provide full opportunities for representatives of the mining company to present and explain their proposal. If the parties fail to agree within 12 months, either the intending miner or the land council or both may request the Minister to refer the matters in dispute between them to a person appointed as a mining commissioner. That person shall be a Federal Court judge appointed by the Attorney-General in consultation with the Commonwealth Ministers responsible for Aboriginal affairs and resources and energy. The mining commissioner shall attempt to conciliate between the parties on the matters in dispute but where such conciliation is not successful, he shall proceed, by arbitration of the matters in dispute, to determine terms and conditions that are fair and reasonable and which in his opinion would have been negotiated by the parties in commercial arms length negotiations concluded in good faith. The mining commissioner will not be limited by the Act as to what matters to take into account, for example he will be able to take into account the value of minerals likely to be mined.

Where the intending miner is willing to enter into an agreement on the terms and conditions determined by the mining commissioner, the land council shall enter that agreement failing which the Minister shall enter into it on the council's behalf. Where the intending miner does not enter into the agreement within 90 days, or such longer time as the Minister determines, of the arbitrator's determination, its exploration licence or lease will be cancelled.

There will also be a provision to guard against a situation where a miner puts forward either an exploration program or a mining proposal so as to obtain the consent of the traditional owners and, after that consent is gained, departs substantially from the original proposal. If such a situation occurs, the relevant land council will be able to apply to the Minister who will have a discretion to decide that his departure from the original proposal was such as would have led to the traditional owners refusing their consent. If he so decides and, excepting where the national interest requires the project to proceed, then the mining interest is invalidated and it is open to the Northern Territory Minister to provide the opportunity for another application to be made to the land council.
Other provisions in the revised exploration and mining provisions of the Bill include-
Retention of the existing power for the Governor-General to proclaim that the grant of a licence is required in the national interest;
Scope for a land council to enter into an agreement relating to exploration or mining on land under claim;

Specifications for the appointment of two assessors to assist the mining commissioner at the exploration agreement stage-one on the nomination of the relevant land council, and the other on the nomination of the Northern Territory Chamber of Mines (Incorporated).
Financial Impact
The only additional cost to the Commonwealth arising from these amendments will be incurred in the event that the arbitral proceedings are involved.
Conclusion

With this Bill and the Bill introduced last year, the Government has made significant improvements to the Act. The amendments will result in a scheme which gives proper recognition to the wider range of interests affected by the Act while continuing to preserve and protect the rights and interests of Aboriginals.

This Bill represents the culmination of a most intensive and thorough process of review and consultation. The compromises that have been reached may not please everybody. What is now required, however, is that all parties recognise that each has legitimate interests, and that the changes proposed represent both an attempt to address in an equitable manner the structural deficiencies in the present Act, and a genuine effort to balance the interests involved, whilst maintaining the fundamental rights that Aboriginal people are able to exercise in relation to their land in the Northern Territory.

The Act remains the most visible symbol of the recognition by the Commonwealth Government of the special relationship between Aboriginals and their land. The Bill maintains the unequivocal and fundamental right of traditional Aboriginal land owners to control resource development on their land, whilst instituting a number of essential reforms which are in the interest of both Aboriginals and the wider Australian community.
Further details of the amendments are contained in the explanatory memorandum being circulated with the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

I think we all know how slow that can be on occasions. It may well be that with these new administrative procedures we do not need a cut-off point because they will all be back on time. I am hopeful that that is the case.

My view on this particular proposal is that, on balance, I still support it. If there is extremely strong opposition-I know it is up to the Minister, but I do not suggest that the Government is encouraged necessarily to bat on with this proposal-it may well be appropriate that the Senate Select Committee on Electoral Reform discuss it again to see whether there is some middle ground. I assume that there would not be any opposition from those opposite if we followed that course and brought in any necessary amendments in a Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill rather than a separate Electoral Bill, but I will leave it to the Minister to respond to that point.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator Robert Ray's final suggestion. Let me make it perfectly clear that I am not suggesting for one minute that in every electorate the returning officers should wait until every vote comes in before declaring the poll. They do not do that now. In any electorate where it is absolutely clear that outstanding votes cannot alter the result, they declare it. I am pointing out something that is fundamental and will occur only in small cases. When the preliminary count has been made and it is clear that the margin is so narrow that the outstanding votes known to exist could influence the result, it is very wrong to declare the result. It is no argument to say: `Oh, in any case you could go to the Court of Disputed Returns'. That is a very long, difficult, unpredictable show and a lot of red herrings are raised in that situation.

SPEECH.PARA: It ought to be possible to devise a form of amendment which holds up declaration of a seat whose result can be influenced by the outstanding absentee votes. That is the only thing I am interested in. I do not believe that that affects, in any imperative way, the worries that Senator Ray has. I think that it can be coped with in any case. We know precisely how many votes there are. In my judgment there is no way in which votes could be outstanding for three months. If, within a week or two, the votes cannot be tracked down and a declaration is made that they are lost, that is all right; we have got a case for the Court of Disputed Returns. But we know where they were collected, we know their number and we are able to find out what method of transit was used. I suggest very strongly to the Special Minister of State (Senator Tate) that he accept the proposition that this particular matter be put aside for the moment and that it be sent back to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform for study.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the Committee's attention to the National Party's amendment No. 3. It is relevant to some of the things that Senator Sir John Carrick has mentioned. We propose a new clause 274a which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, where, at any time before:
(a) the end of the period of 13 days immediately succeeding the close of the poll; or
(b) the declaration of the result of an election;

In other words, the returning officer is not going to declare a poll when it is very close and there are a handful of votes outstanding, which is the problem we all have. One reason we have drawn this amendment up is that there have been cases within the Australian Electoral Commission of votes having been lost temporarily. Our amendment also covers votes that could be lost or mislaid within the postal system. There is always that problem in the rural areas, where people use postal votes a lot and where there are mail services only once a week. We took those cases into account in the drafting of our third amendment. Firstly, votes could be mislaid by the Electoral Commission and, secondly, ballot papers could take longer than necessary to get to the Electoral Commission because of the postal services of this nation. We have two provisos: Votes should be counted up until the end of the 13 days or the declaration of the poll, which the divisional returning officer would declare only if there were an absolute majority at that stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to deal with Senator Collard, my advice is that the proposal of the National Party of Australia has the potential to delay the Senate scrutiny indefinitely while it makes provision for the declaration of the poll to proceed in the House of Representatives election before all outstanding votes have come to hand in cases where those votes cannot affect the outcome. There is no such provision in respect of the Senate. It is not practicable to commence the Senate scrutiny and alter the figures to take account of postal votes subsequently received. The Senate scrutiny cannot commence until all eligible votes are in and the quota is struck. The proposal is, therefore, in effect, that there be no cut-off for the receipt of postal votes. Have I understood correctly what Senator Collard is proposing?

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes. Surely we would know how many votes were outstanding? There would not be many. The number could probably be counted on the fingers of two hands, and maybe the toes of one foot if necessary. I do not see how our proposal would greatly affect the striking of the quota.

—I will try to simplify the situation. There is a difference between postal votes, pre-poll votes and absentee votes. I think they can be readily distinguished and can be dealt with quite separately. The 13 day cut-off is ideal for postal votes because one does not know whether they are all going to get back, when they are going to get back or how they are going to get back. The other votes are in the hands and control of the Electoral Commission right from day one. They should be taken into account. There is no reason for them to be delayed and there is no reason why they should not be in the count right from the start. I believe that the changes I have proposed on behalf of the Opposition would cover that. They would also look after the point that Senator Collard has in mind. I believe it is a very simple course to follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a bit of a problem. Whilst in theory the votes are in the hands of the Australian Electoral Commission, they are, as Senator Robert Ray said, collected by overseas diplomatic staff and returned in batches by courier. So obviously they are not in the control of the Electoral Commission in the same way as they would be if they were in the Denison office of the Commission. So there are difficulties. As I understand it, we have to strike some sort of balance. Of course, if an enrolled person casts a vote one would want to do everything that was humanly possible to ensure that that vote was taken into account in the selection of the members of the Australian Parliament. But there is an Attorney-General's opinion which indicates that there is no close-off date in relation to votes received for this chamber and a quota cannot be struck until one is confident that all those who have cast a vote have had their ballot paper transferred to a place where it can be counted. In that situation we have to strike some sort of balance which will, in some very rare cases, have the effect of disenfranchising some Australian who had voted with full intention and expectation that his vote would be counted.
—Do you recognise the difference between the two-postal votes versus the others?
—Yes. The only real problem is with overseas diplomats. Clause 4 of the Bill states that the Act extends to officers outside Australia. That carries with it section 324 of the Act which states:

SPEECH.PARA: A person who, being an officer, contravenes a provision of this Act . . . or a direction given to him under this Act, is guilty of an offence punishable on conviction by a fine not exceeding $1,000.

It also carries with it section 197 which, I recall for the Senate's benefit, provides for a penalty for the failure to post or deliver a postal ballot paper. Once again the penalty is $1,000. So, together with the new administrative arrangements that are being made and will be insisted upon in relation to overseas posts, the assistant returning officers overseas will be subject to such directions and to the jeopardy of such a heavy penalty that we can expect that the problems which have occurred in the past through sheer negligence will be overcome.

There may still be an occasion when for some reason or another a bag goes astray. In that situation we have to countenance the possibility that we have to set some sort of arbitrary date, close off the matter and allow the quota to be struck for the Senate scrutiny to proceed. That is all we are attempting to do. So I am inclined to go ahead with clause 23.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to be tedious but if the Minister, as he says, can anticipate votes going astray by misadventure, then the logical consequence of what he is saying is for me to say that 13 days is not a reasonable time to try to find the mistake, unwind it and locate the votes. Perhaps he may make it three weeks. A period of 13 days is very short. Anyone who knows what happens in regard to a misadventure which occurs in sending material from overseas to Australia would agree. I suggest that it is not good enough for the Government to say that it has tightened up the procedures and made some punitive arrangements to get things going. It is not just that electors are deprived of the effect of their franchise. The result of an election can hang on a seat. In 1961 the election was decided by one seat. Postal votes could determine, in a difficult case, who shall govern. To turn all this back to the Court of Disputed Returns is to fail to understand the enormous complexity of the matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not see why, just because we may delay the Senate for a moment or two, we should let things stand. The system exists to enable the votes that are validly cast to determine who shall hold the seat. To say `That is not true, we are going to put a caveat on it. We mean only the votes that are validly cast and that get there in 13 days shall decide the seat' is an outrageous proposition. It is a defiance of the situation. We say, with sweet reason, that, as we have all the punitive arrangements now, and if we know where the votes are, then from the word go the pressure should be put on to find out whether all the votes are there. If after 13 days, we have not found them we should keep searching. I suggest to the Minister that he reconsider his opinion and report back to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that the ideal solution to this problem would be to allow the House of Representatives voting to be almost open-ended, up to three or four weeks, and to apply a cut-off point to the Senate of 13 days. It is stretching the imagination to an extreme degree to suggest that those missing votes-I think Senator Collard suggested that one could count them on one's hands-could affect a Senate election. It is almost inconceivable. We are trying to solve one problem which affects two specific areas. I wonder whether it is possible for us to come up with a form of words to solve the Senate position and then maybe go to the three-week rule for the House of Representatives. However, we are talking about a very small number of votes. If that small number of votes is to affect an election result, determining which candidate wins or loses, it will go straight to a Court of Disputed Returns in any event. That is inevitable. It is almost equally inevitable that the decision will be turned over if it involves only a small number of votes and there will be a fresh election.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge one other factor. It is always important in a Court of Disputed Returns to go in as a winner rather than as a loser. In electoral history there has been a tendency for sitting members to be returned, especially if the case goes ahead relatively quickly and without controversy. Therefore, there is an advantage in having every vote in in determining a winner. I can assure honourable senators from experience that the worst thing in the world is to have a tie and then have a pull out of the hat. One gets none of the advantages of incumbency and all the disadvantages of going to the Court of Disputed Returns. But there is some advantage in being a winner. Maybe at some stage we could consider having a set cut-off point for the Senate such as 13 days, which I do not think would be controversial, and maybe a three-week rule for the House of Representatives.

There are problems. Senator Sir John Carrick said that governments could be determined on this issue. Not only governments but also leadership and Prime Ministers could be so determined by not having someone here to vote for who is going to be Prime Minister or who is going to be in the ministry. So it works both ways. It could well affect the future.

We have not worried about this point in the past prior to the Nunawading case. I think the various divisional returning officers had an arbitrary cut-off date and went ahead with a declaration, irrespective of whether there were votes outstanding. It was very hard for us to find out, especially prior to freedom of information. We simply would not have known. I do not think there is anything malevolent or suspicious about a government saying: `Given the Nunawading decision, we have decided to put in a cut-off point'. I would have to agree, though, that I would not like that ever to be used to influence an election result. But at the same time I am conscious of the fact that even with the other amendments put into this Bill it takes weeks and weeks to have a Senate election result declared. To put in something without control at the moment-there is nothing prospective in any of the amendments to control it-may involve a long delay.

I suspect that at the next election that will not be a problem because the Senate term goes to 1 July, there has to be a House of Representatives election before April and there will be a good eight or nine weeks to count. But what will happen in the future if we have a 25 May or later election, even a June election, and we need to have senators sworn by 1 July, or at least available on 1 July? That simply will not be possible if we have an open-ended situation. I guess that what I am saying, having listened to all the contributions, is that all of us have contributed some wisdom but none of us have contributed comprehensive wisdom to this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been worn down. I would like to see this Bill passed by 7 o'clock or whenever we adjourn. When is it?
—It is 6.30.

—In any case, I am going to give in. I am prepared to withdraw the amendment that I was suggesting to clause 23. However, I do so on the basis that, at the earliest possible stage in the Budget session, in a statute law miscellaneous amendments Bill, or even in a Bill of one clause-because one never knows when an election will be upon us and we may not have time to get through the whole process normally attendant on presenting a statute law miscellaneous amendment Bill to the Senate-and having considered this matter in the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform, we pass speedily a form of words which allows us to strike a quota for the Senate as soon as is practical after the election.
—Is leave granted for Senator Tate to withdraw his amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the Minister's remarks. We would be perfectly happy for the matter to be considered by the Senate Committee in due course on that understanding.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

Clause negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 15, clause 27, proposed subsection 211a (1), lines 4 to 9, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:
``(1) Where:
(a) a candidate in a Senate election is:
(i) a Senator; or
(ii) in the case of an election following a dissolution of the Senate, a person who was, immediately before the dissolution, a Senator; and
(b) the candidate has not joined in a request under section 168 in relation to the election;

the candidate may lodge with the Australian Electoral Officer a written statement that the candidate wishes voters in the election to indicate their preferences in relation to all the candidates in the election in an order specified in the statement, being an order that gives preference to the candidate lodging the statement before any other candidate.''.
The implications of the amendment I think are clear to honourable senators. This merely clarifies a matter.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall move an amendment circulated in my name on behalf of the Australian Democrats to insert new clauses after clause 40. The substantive item I have already dealt with at fair length at the second reading stage. Owing to the lateness of the hour I do not propose to do that again. We are looking at a very small band of statements which can be true or untrue. We are not looking at that whole range of statements about what governments will be doing or might do or have any intention of doing; we are looking only at statements of the kind that I mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

This amendment changes the cut off date for receipt of postal votes from 14 days to 13 days after the close of the poll to ensure that the cut-off falls on a normal postal delivery day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 24, clause 36, at end of clause add the following new subclause:

``(2) Where, apart from this subsection, the disclosure period, for the purposes of section 305 of the Principal Act, as amended by this Act, in relation to an election would have commenced on a day before the commencement of this Act, that section, as amended by this Act, applies as if the disclosure period in relation to the election commenced on the date of commencement of this Act or on the day of issue of the writ for the election, whichever is the earlier.''.

This is a non-contentious clause and the amendment I have moved is not subject to any great debate. It inserts a new sub-clause to ensure that the disclosure period applicable to third parties at the next election under section 305 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act will run only for the date on which the Commonwealth Electoral Amendment Bill comes into effect or the date of issue of writs for the election, whichever is earlier. Of course, this is entirely in harmony with our general policy of avoiding the imposition of retrospective obligations on persons-in this case third parties caught up in section 305 of the Act.
Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 24, clause 36, lines 14 to 33, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
``Repeal of Division 4 of Part XX
``36. Division 4 of Part XX of the Principal Act is repealed.''.

I will be brief as I recognise that we have a fair chance of passing this Bill tonight. It has never been National Party of Australia policy to disclose the source of election funds. The disclosure of where a party gets its funds from is tantamount to disclosure of where its support is. It is also getting to the stage of showing how certain people or certain sections of the community will vote. Also, there is the possibility of retribution. People in the business community in particular run the risk of a government which they did not support saying that they are marked men. I realise that the quid pro quo of that is that if funds dry up, as indeed they do and have done, there is public funding, which of course I am also against. That was indicated in the amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Bill which was moved and supported by our Liberal colleagues. It is obvious which side of politics this disclosure affects. The Australian Labor Party does not deny that it receives vast sums from the trade union movement. We acknowledge that these tax deductible funds are available. We also know that paid union officials work for the ALP at election time without any disclosure. Our policy-it is a basic principle-has always been against disclosure of funds because such disclosure shows who people support and that breaches what we understand democracy is all about.
Amendment negatived.
Clause, as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 37 to 40-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Proposed new clause 40a.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 26, after clause 40, insert the following new clause:
``40a. Section 329 of the Principal Act is amended:
(a) by inserting after subsection (1) the following subsection:
`(2) A person shall not, during the relevant period in relation to an election under this Act, authorise to be printed, published or distributed, any electoral matter containing a statement:
(a) that is untrue; and
(b) that is, or is likely to be, misleading or deceptive.'; and
(b) by inserting `, (2)' after `sub-section (1)' in subsection (4).''.

As I was saying before when I jumped the gun somewhat, this amendment seeks to impose upon politicians an obligation that is on ordinary companies operating in the community with regard to their representations to the community. Clearly, only a very small band of statements would be caught up but they at least should be caught up. I gave an example. To be brief, I will repeat the same example. A statement which would be caught up is a statement that in the party platform of the Australian Labor Party says that the ALP is going to introduce a capital gains tax. That fairly obviously is a statement, with regard to the last election, which would be false. A statement which would not be caught up under this provision is one that Senator Archer referred to-that is: `The Australian Labor Party will introduce a capital gains tax'. As I suggested, fairly obviously at that stage it is a matter of grist for the mill. As it turned out, that statement was true. It would not have been caught up because it is a prediction about a future proposition which cannot be either true or false in itself until the time arrives and that time is after the election, if it is a prediction of the next government's activities. Anyone can look, as I have done, at the laws that have flowed from the operation of those sections of the Trade Practices Act. There is now a clearly worked out basis in law on how those particular obligations operate, are to be imposed, what will occur, how it will occur and the types of defences available to people resulting from those obligations not to mislead the community about services or products.

I believe that this proposal should be included as a first step. Indeed, I believe that the community expects of us standards far higher than they expect from companies. We should be prepared to have in the legislation that governs our activities the same impositions that we impose on others with regard to truthfulness about products and the way that they are represented to the community. I do not intend to discuss this matter at length, because it is hoped that the Bill will be passed tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform has discussed the matter in very great depth. It had it in mind that if there were ways that could reasonably be seen to ensure that untruths or wilfully misleading statements could be removed from campaigning, that path should be pursued. Let it be clear that because the Committee members, including me, are not supporting the amendment, it is not an indication that we want to leave open the grounds to enable people to fly high, wide and handsome.

SPEECH.PARA: The jury considering statements made during election campaigns comprises the electors themselves. Indeed, the very nature of the ballot box is a judgment by the people of not only whether this or that policy is right but also whether, inherent in that, they have been misled and whether statements are untrue or are likely to be misleading.

As I understand the evidence given to the Committee, the weight of legal opinion was that such a provision could be so used that election results could be deferred or even overthrown in a chaotic manner. In any case, one must ask why, during the relevant period of an election campaign-which I take to mean the writ period of 25 days-it is wrong to mislead or tell untruths, but it is all right for the remaining 340 days of the year.

The matter is complex and I do not want to delay the Senate. I simply suggest that the volume of evidence put before the Committee shows that this proposal could be widely used for vexatious purposes, or that even if it were used sincerely, it could create chaos. Indeed, the cost of attempting to decide the intent of a person is very real.

Time and time again all of us have made statements here that we believed to be true, but which in future could be shown to be untrue. They could also, however unwittingly, have been misleading. There is no suggestion in the proposal that the intention of a person or party must be proved. On plain words, the statements are either untrue, misleading or likely to be misleading, whatever the intention of the person or party. I think that we are in a wilderness on this matter. The electoral system has worked pretty well so far. There have been no major cases of someone putting a massively misleading position before the people as a confidence trick, which has therefore disrupted the democratic process. I believe in the good sense of the jury. If there is to be any such provision, I would want it to be for 365 days of the year, for each year, for three years-not just trying to keep the illegitimates honest during the days of the writ period.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are a number of problems with the amendment moved by Senator Macklin, but I congratulate him on its nature compared with the one three years ago, to which I objected most strongly. I do not have the same strong objection to this amendment, but I do not know whether it will achieve as much as Senator Macklin would wish. There are three problems. The first is how do we define what is untrue? Secondly, how do we define what is misleading and deceptive, and thirdly, how do we define what is deceptive? I think that the courts will look to the debates in Parliament for some guidance, although it does not appear that we will have a long debate to guide them. It is very hard to define what is true or untrue and what is likely to mislead or otherwise. Nevertheless, perhaps the attempt is worth while.

SPEECH.PARA: The real problem is that in seeking to avoid having the misfits of the electoral process taking constant injunctions, Senator Macklin limited the proposal to the Australian Electoral Commission. His motives in that were absolutely proper, but I can imagine the pressure that will suddenly come on the Commission. It is going to be in the gunsight. If we refer to it something that we regard as untrue or misleading, and it refuses to take out an injunction, all our candidates and supporters will say that it is biased. If it does take out an injunction, the other side will accuse it of bias. Given the other pressures on the Commission at the time, I think that it would be extremely difficult for it to carry out the proposed task.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, the Government will not be supporting the amendment, for the reasons so eloquently expressed by Senator Sir John Carrick and Senator Robert Ray and contained in the report of the Committee.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

QUESTION.PARA: What action has been taken within the CSIRO to make personnel management practices more flexible.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Achieving the objective of more flexible personnel management practices is a long term matter. It involves adopting new approaches to a range of personnel policies. The success with these will depend in part upon how well the perception of managers, staff and staff associations about existing policies can be changed. For this reason, changes will be introduced over a period of time rather than as a single exercise.

Areas in which CSIRO will be endeavouring to achieve greater flexibility include recruitment, staff rewards, personnel management and mobility. CSIRO is re-examining, for example, its practices in the use of contract staffing, performance appraisal, performance pay systems, superannuation, staff appeals, redundancy, redeployment, involuntary retirement, and staff exchanges and secondments.

A formal Performance Review and Development Program will be introduced at the beginning of the 1987/88 financial year. By July 1987 the Early Separation Incentive Scheme will have concluded resulting in the separation of some 250 staff thereby contributing significantly to CSIRO's capacity to redeploy resources as well as to mobility. CSIRO will shortly be examining, with the Department of Finance, revised superannuation arrangements to facilitate mobility into and from CSIRO. A more streamlined approach to managing staff appeals is currently being worked out.
The Government's general policy on streamlining is of assistance to CSIRO in achieving this important objective.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 18 February 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: Why is it not practicable to split funding for the Drug Offensive on a State/Territory basis. (See Answer to Question on Notice No 1254, Weekly Hansard, 10 December 1986, P. 3771).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: As I advised in my answer to the honourable senator's earlier question the Drug Offensive is the information/media element of the National Campaign Against Drug Abuse and has included Australia-wide activities such as the National Drug Information Line. Other activities have included a nation-wide booklet distribution, a national advertising and information campaign and other activities, the benefits and costs of which have been spread throughout all States and Territories. The Drug Offensive is not a grants program or a cost-shared program, therefore it would be impossible to quantify expenditures in each State and Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 3 April 1987 (Hansard, page 1821) Senator Jessop asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Is the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs able to inform the Senate of the direct cost to the Commonwealth involved in transporting, accommodating and promoting Mr Oliver Tambo, the leader of the self-professed terrorist organisation the African National Congress, and his entourage on their visit to Australia . . . Can the Minister also inform the Senate of the estimated cost of the security arrangements for this visit and also the cost of the security arrangements for his visit to Nareen this weekend?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question.

The cost of air travel, accommodation and meals for Mr Tambo and three accompanying staff amounted to $39,000. Ground transport charges have yet to be brought to account but are estimated at approximately $17,000, giving a probable total expenditure of the order of $56,000. Security for the visitors including the visit to Nareen was provided by police forces in each of the Australian states visited and no charges accrued to the Commonwealth for these services.
Costs undertaken by New Zealand and Japan, the two other countries visited by Mr Tambo following his tour in Australia, are understood to have been on an equivalent scale.
